Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Mobile phones have become an ever-present part of our society bringing to the forefront increasing concerns related to security. Mobile devices are being used to commit crimes and are becoming a target to gain user information for harmful intentions. Mobile security remains a top concern to businesses. The project advances both knowledge and education in the field of mobile cybersecurity and cyber forensics by creating an online Mobile Forensics and Security (MFS) certificate program and developing and implementing a train-the-trainer program for Computer Information Systems faculty. This will increase Robert Morris University's capacity to train MFS specialists and the capacity of other institutions to offer programs in this area once their faculty has been trained.

The project will provide the MFS train-the-trainer program through onsite and online training programs using Blackboard and VMWare to 20 faculty members by the end of the grant period, and annually thereafter and offer an online certificate program in Mobile Forensics and Security by Fall 2016. The certificate program will be combined with hands on internships that will equip students with the skills needed to secure a mobile environment. Through partnerships with Middle Georgia State College and Southeastern Advanced Cybersecurity Education Consortium that serve a large number of African American students and rural students, the project will expand training and certificate course offerings for these underrepresented groups. As a result of the project, by 2018-2019, at least 20 additional faculty members will be trained and fully equipped to teach mobile forensics. They, in turn, will be able to train others on their campuses and potentially impact thousands of students trained in mobile security, thereby improving cybersecurity in a variety of U.S. industry sectors and government.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mobile phones have become an ever-present part of our society bringing to the forefront increasing concerns related to security. Mobile security remains a top concern to businesses, organizations and the government. The project advanced both knowledge and education in the field of mobile cybersecurity and cyber forensics by implementing a train-the-trainer program for computing faculty and creating an online Mobile Forensics and Security (MFS) certificate program at Robert Morris University. This project increased the university’s capacity to train MFS specialists and the capacity of other institutions to offer programs in mobile forensics and security. The project has:

Goal #1: Develop an online certificate program in Mobile Forensics and Security

An online Mobile Forensics and Security certificate was developed from existing courses in the Cyber Forensics and Security degree along with one new course titled Mobile Security Policy. The certificate and new course went through the university’s curriculum process for review and approval. The certificate and new course were available to students for the Spring schedule of 2016. As of the date of this report, 67 students have completed the Mobile Forensics and Security certificate and 236 students have taken the Mobile Policy course as part of the certificate or an open elective. Links to the certificate and course are listed below:

Certificate:  https://sentry.rmu.edu/OnTheMove/wpmajdegr.show_checksheet?ipage=1195&iattr=M&icksht=2019U11

Course: https://sentry.rmu.edu/OnTheMove/wpcrsehist.get_results?icalledby=WPMAJDEGR&it=&ipage=1195&iattr=M&itrm=201860&icrse=INFS3110&ishowHdr=1&iShowReg=Yes

 

Goal #2: Develop a training program for CIS faculty to enable additional RMU faculty and faculty from other institutions to teach mobile forensics and security courses

A hands-on train-the-trainer program was developed in Mobile Forensics and Security using Parabens Electronic Evidence Examiner. A solicitation for faculty to attend the training was sent out throughout the 2-years of the grant. The training was provided at no cost to the faculty. Faculty were given a pre-and post-test to the training consisting of 25 questions. There was in increase in knowledge from the pre-test to the post-test for all 25 questions. Faculty were trained via lectures and hands-on labs. During the last day of the training faculty were required to take a practical exam to demonstrate their understanding of the new skills. Upon successful completion of the training faculty were given a certificate of completion and a copy of the training material.

Goal #3: Provide a Mobile Forensics and Security (MFS) train-the-trainer program to 20 faculty by the end of the grant period

During the two-year grant period 43 faculty members from universities throughout the U.S. were trained on-ground at Robert Morris University and 18 were trained through a virtual environment. Additionally, four faculty members from RMU were trained. The grant was approved a no-cost extension for two years which allowed us to train an additional 118 faculty from partner institutions to include Middle Georgia State University, the University of Hawaii, Maui College and the University of Maine, Augusta. As a result, the project trained 145 faculty over its projected number. The surplus has allowed additional faculty to be trained on their campuses and potentially impact thousands of students trained in mobile security, thereby improving cybersecurity knowledge in a variety of industry and government sectors.
